body: @jdeppe-pivotal Looks good!

@demery-pivotal 

I pushed two commits:
* Fixup testing scenario numbers
* Add missing test ConnectionConfigImplTest (I found it in the original branch - hope I didn't miss any other files or tests)

ConnectionConfigImpl implements ConnectionConfig interface using java.util.Properties. I'm tempted to rename ConnectionConfigImpl to PropertiesConnectionConfig or PropertiesBasedConnectionConfig.

The script is now much more useful for local testing, outside the context of Concourse.  Multiple variables files can be specified, as demonstrated in the meta pipeline scripts.  Raw, command-line variables can also be specified.  These are parsed by the `yaml.load` parser, and as such accepts any valid YML or JSON string.

The script is also hardened against interpolating variables that are not specified, as the Jinja default is to interpolate unspecified variables to an empty string.  This initially caused a few errors, as things were interpolating to empty, perhaps without our collective knowledge.

For this reason, there are two `TODO`s in this PR.  Notably:

* What should the default value of  `benchmarks.baseline_branch` be?  How is it handled when this had been blank?  @balesh2 @pivotal-jbarrett, do either of you have context on that?

* What should the default value of `test.PARALLEL_GRADLE` be?  Should we permit a default value, or require that a valid test spec has this value?  I see that there is a safeguard check in the `execute_*` scripts that sets it to true.  It seems to me that we should set that here rather than interpret downstream that blank means "yes do parallel."  Thoughts, @smgoller @rhoughton-pivot?
@Petahhh

In VSD, I can see every statistics instance showing the PID now in the PID column with one exception: StatSamplerStats. If I review the constructor of StatSamplerStats, I see that it uses InternalDistributedSystem.getId() for the numericId both before and after GEODE-6269: Extract StatisticsRegistry from IDS (#3068) so I don't think we changed the behavior for StatSamplerStats. I could change it to be the PID as well, but that's new behavior rather than restoring what was previously there.
What's up with github?

I filed an improvement ticket to change the numericId of StatSamplerStats: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6486

I'd like to keep this PR focused on fixing GEODE-6442.

This PR hasn't seen any action for over three months.  I'm going to go ahead and close it.  If there is still active work in progress, don't hesitate to reopen it, assuming the above concerns have been addressed.
@Petahhh
This PR is two and a half months stale, but it had been approved.  Can anyone with context on it resolve the conflicts and get it through?
RegionMappingTest is failing
AnalyzeConnectorsSerializablesJUnitTest is failing
the jdbc loader, writer, and asyncWriter IntegrationTests are failing
Interesting!  LGTM
DistributedTestOpenJDK8 has a flaky failure in `PartitionedRegionStatsDUnitTest.testDataStoreEntryCount` which is unrelated to this PR.

lgtm
very readable code
Tested locally in a private concourse, but the `meta` pipeline successfully spins up and deploys the other pipes, so each `deploy_*` script seems to be working fine.
@Petahhh
@Petahhh
It cannot resolve the issue. We have other alternatives.

~~Yep.~~  Also the rendered `str` doesn't have a `.render()` method, so, you know, that immediately errors out.

[edit:] No, wait... The variables get passed into the environment explicitly in the `render` call.  The environment resolves things like finding files by name, such as our shared macros in the `shared/` folder.  It also handled the initial discovery of the template itself, but that's already happened before the lines of this PR's diff.
failed test is a flaky test not related to this changeset
@Petahhh
This change is beyond the scope of our pipeline to test. I'm going to merge it now
Could you please review this PR @onichols-pivotal @jdeppe-pivotal @jinmeiliao? Thank you!
@Petahhh For your review

I'm looking at the public API in this pull request, and I'm having a hard time figuring out how a user is supposed to use it or understand how it will work. I see a MetricsPublishingService interface and what looks like a ServiceLoader in the internal code but there is no documentation for the user on how to plug in their MetricsPublishingService.

I also feel like this ServiceLoader mechanism may not the best way for users to plugin in their MetricsPublishingService - would it be better for them to pass it in to CacheFactory/ClientCacheFactory? Creating a jar that implements a service is a bit of a pain for users to have to go through, and makes it more difficult for them to test their code. If you go and write up a simple example of how use micrometer with geode that we can add to the javadocs I think you'll see what I mean!
@upthewaterspout I think using the service loader is a great first start. If we think adding a method to one of the factory methods is useful we can always add it later.
Does this relates to any future plan of removing the gfs files?
any idea why the pmd check failed on this change?  the error suggests it is finding some public mutator in the new Enum, but I don't see anything wrong with it...

@doribd The current approach is to build out new metrics capabilities based on micrometer in a side-by-side mode.  If/when the micrometer work reaches parity with the existing gfs-based statistics, we can determine the best course of action based on community input.

@upthewaterspout I like the idea to pass in an implementation of MetricsPublishingService to CacheFactory/ClientCacheFactory! That sounds like a great alternative to defining a service in the Jar file. I think I would propose supporting both approaches.
Obviously-unrelated failure in DUnit appears to be [GEODE-4267](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-4267).
@pivotal-jbarrett We're talking about adding in the CacheFactory/ClientCacheFactory setters later but going forward with the ServiceLoader mechanism. Would you mind adding your review?
@rhoughton-pivot - Sai ran into it on the release/1.9.0 branch. It was definitely crazy to track down, and one more reason to be annoyed with gradle :)

The current failure from pmd says

>All static final fields must be immutable objects. No mutable static state is allowed.

Switching this

`public static final RegionShortcut DEFAULT_REGION_TYPE = RegionShortcut.PARTITION`

to 

`public final RegionShortcut DEFAULT_REGION_TYPE = RegionShortcut.PARTITION`

seems to fix this issue.

@PurelyApplied do you have any thoughts on this?
let's get rid of the default_type declaration, no one is using it anyway. let's just directly put RegionShortcut.PARTITION in the code that used this static down below.
The concourse jobs failed because repo.spring.io is down. But I don't think concourse will even pick up this change because it's part of the pipeline configuration.
👏 I attempted this once before and failed.  Sounds great!!!

the integration tests are timing out because the following hangs: org.apache.geode.cache.client.internal.ConnectionPoolImplJUnitTest.testExecuteOp()
This test creates a mocked Op whose attempt method always throws: SocketTimeoutException.
org.apache.geode.cache.client.internal.OpExecutorImpl.execute(Op, int) has some exception handling that end up calling exchangeConnection and your new implementation of it ends up always creating a connection. So we retry and keep getting the SocketTimeoutException. The retry logic keeps adding the server that failed to a set of servers to ignore. So the old exchange would eventually throw NoAvailableServersException once all the servers were added to the attemptedServers set.
Did we update the javadoc as per Jen's suggestion?

> Did we update the javadoc as per Jen's suggestion?

Hey Jinmei, we just fixed it this morning. Thank you!
PersistentRecoveryOrderOldConfigDUnitTest failed suspect string caused by DistributedSystemDisconnectedException. Unrelated to this PR.

Regarding the PMD failure - that PMD rule is not particularly clever - in particular it's not good at figuring out if the value of your static field is actually immutable. In this case you could annotate the static final field with @Immutable to make the thing stop complaining if you've confirmed the value is immutable.
Thanks @upthewaterspout !!

One concern about moving RegionShortcut to geode-management is that with java modules (java 9 and up), you are not supposed to have the same package in more than one jar. So once we actually make geode-core and geode-management into jigsaw modules this class will be a problem if it is in geode-management since it's in a geode-core package.

@PurelyApplied  probably knows more about what we want to do about duplicate packages.

One of the dunit failures was a known flaky issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-6462. This same test passed on DistributedTestOpenJDK11 and on a rerun.
So we are down to one dunit failure: ClientServerFunctionExecutionDUnitTest.testOnServerExecution_FunctionInvocationTargetException()
@Petahhh For your review
Closing until we're ready to make a real PR for this
@Petahhh
I would make sure we refer to it as non-locking. It does block during create connection but does not lock when getting from the pool.
Thanks. I was writing it in a hurry before going to lunch. That was a typo

Closing out this PR for now because it needs more work.
The single failure in UpgradeTestOpenJDK8 is a testing issue not an issue with this PR.

To add some context to this change. If you look at the current [benchmark results in the CI](https://concourse.apachegeode-ci.info/teams/main/pipelines/apache-develop-main?groups=complete) you will notice the get based benchmarks. Those are currently pegged at this throughput rate regardless of the number of threads thrown at the client above about 32 threads. By removing the lock contention in the connection pool the throughput with ~600 threads is nearly 3 times as fast and can continue to scale up with threads and processors.

You can run these benchmarks yourself. See http://github.com/apache/geode-benchmarks. Keep in mind your mileage may vary depending on your hardware. The CI uses dedicated AWS instances with 36 processing units and the 10Gb+ enhanced networking in the same placement group.

It's also possible that GEODE-6534: Make NonTXEntry entryIsDestroyed volatile #3318 will fix some of the above flakiness. Notice that it's involves entry destroyed in NonTXEntry and this branches does not include #3318.

It looks to me like what this test depends on is that prefill will create a connection. But, at least the initial prefill does not happen because it thinks we are already at the min of one because at the same time the prefill thread checked to see if count was at min, another test thread tried to connect. It failed but while it is trying to connect it sets count to 1. Still debugging to see why prefill did not get rescheduled later.
We accidently changed borrowConnection to no longer call startBackgroundPrefill() if it fail to create a connection and decs the count back down. I will push a fix for this.

> org.apache.geode.test.concurrency.ConcurrentTestRunnerTest

This may be a concurrency difference between hosts. Since this tests is trying to expose a know concurrency issue to test that the concurrency test framework can find such issues its possible that load or configuration or whatever prevents the test from failing as expected.
